page.title: 09PADBURY SICK BENEFIT SOCIETY
page.content: Padbury Sick Benefit Society claims to be one of the oldest still existing. A rule book of 1836 has been found when it was called the Padbury and Hilllesden Friendly Society. Some aspects of the rules were found difficult to adhere to and in 1856 the Padbury Sick Benefit Society was founded whose aims were easier to achieve. The members, of whom there were 90 in 1881, paid a quarterly sum of 3 shillings. Money was paid out in the event of illness or lameness. When a member died his wife or next of kin was given 3 for funeral expenses. The society's meeting place was the "White Horse", now a private house. It now meets at the "Blackbird". Their Feast Day is on Spring Bank Holiday weekend. The festivities include a dinner, dance, church service and a procession through the village.
